"THE ART OF ORNAMENTATION\
\
A Reference For Jewelers\
\
CONTENTS\
\
2. Introduction\
3. Metals \& Shapes\
4. Stones \& Designs\
5. Measures of Proficiency\
6. Novice\
7. Junior Apprentice\
8. Senior Apprentice\
9. Fellowcraft\
10. Journeyman\
11. Artisan\
12. Senior Artisan\
13. Master\
14. Master Adept\
15. Grand Master\
16. Updates"

"INTRODUCTION\
\
Jewelers possess the special training required to adjust and customize items of personal adornment (rings, necklaces, etc). They are also capable of setting decorative stones into certain non-jewelry items such as weapons.\
\
The breadth of the Jeweler's art is truly unmatched among the craftspeople of Castle Marrach. Twelve basic metals can be shaped into over thirty basic forms with nearly fifty design variations, and optionally adorned from a selection of over forty gems and minerals.\
\
After a jewelry item is completed, it may be engraved with a symbol by an engraver; jewelers are encouraged to acquire skill in this related craft."

"METALS \& SHAPES\
\
Jewelers ply their art upon metals, skillfully working them into shapes of different complexity and appeal. Novices can select common metals such as tin or lead, while more experienced artisans gain access to highly desireable choices, including silver and gold.\
\
Simple shapes such as squares and triangles can be successfully undertaken by Apprentices. However, many years of skill and experience are required to attempt the more challenging forms. Only a Master jeweler would dare to coax an expensive piece of metal into a helix or toroid!"

"STONES \& DESIGNS\
\
Some persons prefer simple jewelry without adornment. However, those who desire to accent their accessories with precious stones will need the skills of a jeweler.\
\
The proficiency required to work a stone depends upon its rarity, and also upon the difficulty of cutting and polishing. Novices must be content to practice upon common mudstone and mica chips, but concentrated study will earn the ability to set costly gems such as rubies, emeralds and sapphires.\
\
Dozens of unique design variations are also available to the ambitious jeweler, from the \\"common\\" or \\"uninspired\\" attempts of the Novice to the \\"superb\\" artistic statements of the Master."

"MEASURES OF PROFICIENCY\
\
Ten levels of proficiency are recognized for the Jeweling skill:\
\
1. Novice\
2. Junior Apprentice\
3. Senior Apprentice\
4. Fellowcraft\
5. Journeyman\
6. Artisan\
7. Senior Artisan\
8. Master\
9. Master Adept\
10. Grand Master\
\
The following chapters describe the Metal, Shape, Stone and Design options available to jewelers at each level of proficiency."

"NOVICE\
\
Novices are the least experienced jewelers. Their ornamentation skills are admittedly rather limited and pedestrian.\
\
They work in the inexpensive materials of none, tin, or lead.\
\
They produce indifferent shapes, such as none, irregular, or squarish.\
\
They practice their limited skills with none, granite, pumice, mudstone, or mica.\
\
Their designs typically can be described as none, common, amateurish, nondescript, or uninspired."

"JUNIOR APPRENTICE\
\
Junior Apprentices know a bit more than Novices, but their additional skills can hardly be called impressive.\
\
They have mastered the use of copper\
\
They can mold the shapes square, rectangular, and oblong.\
\
The decorative stones quartz, marble, coral, milkstone, and hematite are employed by these students.\
\
Additional designs, such as simple, basic, ordinary, serviceable, and rustic are often produced by these jewelers."

"SENIOR APPRENTICE\
\
Senior Apprentices have attained sufficient skill to attempt a handful of modest but useful ornamentation options.\
\
They can now cast iron.\
\
The shapes triangular, trapezoidal, and eccentric are employed by these jewelers.\
\
Some semi-precious stones, including onyx, jasper, zircon, marcasite, and jade are used by these craftsmen.\
\
Their designs begin to have some appeal, being described as primitive, contemporary, strange, odd, or quaint."

"FELLOWCRAFT\
\
Fellowcraft jewelers have spent many hours learning their trade, and may apply a personal mark to items which they have embellished.\
\
They have gained the skill to work with pewter.\
\
They can produce items in the shapes known as pentagonal, hexagonal, septagonal, and octagonal.\
\
Some slightly more valuable stones, such as agate, amethyst, aquamarine, serpentine, and garnet appear in their creations.\
\
Their jewels are sometimes exotic, unusual, curious, advanced, or whimsical."

"JOURNEYMAN\
\
Journeymen possess the confidence to work with ornamentation options of particular grace and appeal.\
\
Brass and nickel are within the scope of their skill.\
\
Their craft can produce items shaped as semicircular, circular, or elliptical.\
\
They work with precious stones, such as smokestone, obsidian, beryl, carnelian, and opal.\
\
Their designs, very popular among the up-and-coming, are fashionable, elaborate, bold, daring, and extravagant."

"ARTISAN\
\
Artisans have proven themselves capable of the fine control needed to handle some of the more challenging materials and designs.\
\
They work in bronze and steel.\
\
They can produce the shapes convex, concave, spherical, and ovoid.\
\
More precious stones, including topaz, lodestone, citrine, turquoise, and catseye appear among their creations.\
\
The impressive, fine, formal, striking, or ceremonial designs they craft are certain heirlooms."

"SENIOR ARTISAN\
\
Senior Artisans are sought by those desiring rare forms and minerals for their apparel. They often serve as assistants to Master jewelers.\
\
They might work in silver.\
\
They can produce the shapes crescent, cardioid, teardrop, and piscine.\
\
The precious stones bloodstone, chrysoprase, snakestone, pearl, and amber decorate their work.\
\
Their designs are antique, noble, eerie, rare, or subtle."

"MASTER\
\
Masters are the virtuosi of the Jeweler's art. Their long career of study and craftsmanship has given them the ability to work with materials and forms of the most rarified quality. They can also alter the Metal, Shape, Stone and Design of items that have already been altered.\
\
They work with gold.\
\
They can produce the shapes helical, conchate, and toroidal.\
\
The gemstones ruby, sapphire, emerald, alexandrite, and snowstone are used by these craftsment to beautify their jewels.\
\
The designs they produce can be disturbing at times: eldritch, blasphemous, archaic, superb, and diabolical."

"MASTER ADEPT\
\
Master Adepts are usually the pre-eminent expert jewelers within the castle. Their skills and judgement are usually at the beck and call of lords and ladies of the Court.\
\
They work in the rare metal, platinum.\
\
Their jewels might have the shape of parabolic, tesselated, or vermiform.\
\
They might decorate jewels with moonstone, heliotrope, or sardonyx.\
\
Their designs are ancient, righteous, fell, majestic, or angelic."

"GRAND MASTER\
\
Many seasons may pass between the presence of Grand Master jewelers within the castle. When these perfectionists reach this pinnacle of art, their skills are available only to the most distinguished and noble guests.\
\
They know the secret of working with skymetal.\
\
They can make jewels in the shape of a snowflake or a tesseract.\
\
They embellish their jewels with the fantastic gemstones diamond, plasma, and meteorite\
\
Their designs are described as royal, imperial, or transcendent."

"UPDATES\
\
As fashion changes and the art increases, new symbols, shapes and materials will be discovered by the castle's jewelers and other craftsmen. The text of this book will mysteriously update itself as new choices become available. More senior craftsmen will inform you if and when updates occur.\
\
Please bring typographical errors or other textual problems found in this volume to the attention of the staff."
